entry.title: Summaries of a book â€”â€” Make Your Own Neural Network
entry.content:
Prologue

This is my first time to write a blog in English and so I would like to explain reasons which encourage me to do this. Briefly, it can help me learn. First, because I am a Chinese native speaker, I can write slower and have more time to acquire and understand the knowledge in the book totally. Second, codes and functions are written by English in this book. Thus, thinking in the same language will help me avoid issues of translation, especially the special words in codes. Last but not least, the process can be credit to improve my English skills which is very superficial.

Make Your Own Neural Network is a basic introduced book for people who hope to know mechanisms of neural network and machine learning. Even if people donâ€™t want to learn programming, the simple explanation can teach them how a computer simulates neural cells to work like the humanâ€™s brain. There are the bookâ€™s links at Douban, Amazon and my mindnote, final code backup at Github.

Mechanism

A new age inspired by a nature

After the computer having popularized, many boring and tough tasks are no longer difficult for people, such as calculating millions of numbers. Although computers can deal with complex multi-problems simultaneously, they have no ability to identify is there a cat or a baby in a photo. Therefore, people say why not try to build artificial brains by copying how real biological brains worked? The next step is that using programs to make machines cope with tasks just like what human neural cells do.

A simple predicting machine

Like all computer systems, we should have an input and an output with some calculation in between. Compared with math solutions, we may do not know how the process happen. So we could only use a model with parameters which we can adjust to represent this mysterious process. After that, a good method to refine these models is to adjust the parameters based on how wrong the model is compared to know true examples.

Training a simple classifier

Training data means that examples of truth used to teach a predictor or a classifier.

Through these graphs, we can know how to use the error to inform how we adjust the slope. We can use the equation âˆ†A = E / x to update the original A many times and simply match the last training example closely. Besides, we need use learning rate to moderate the updates which is helpful to avoid errors and noises from the real world.

But one classifier is not enough. It cannot separate data where that data itself isnâ€™t governed by a single linear process. Boolean functions, AND, OR, XOR are also very necessary when we just use multiple linear classifiers to divide up data.

Neurons, natureâ€™s computing machines

Neurons all transmit an electrical signal from one end to the other, from dendrites along the axons to the terminals. It takes an electric input, and pops out another electrical signal. They do not react readily but instead suppress the input until it has grown so large that it triggers and output. We can use the logistic function to simulate the processâ€™s characteristic.

One way to replicate this from nature to an artificial model is to have layers of neurons, with each connected to every other one in the preceding and subsequent layer. By this method, our computer model will also attain the ability to be incredibly resilient to damage and imperfect signals just like human brains. To make the model learn, we should adjust the strength of connections between nodes. Therefore, the mechanism ought to de-emphasize a weight which lead to the wrong answer and raise the weight which lead to the right answer.

Matrix multiplication is useful

First, matrix allow us to compress writing all those calculations into a very simple short form. Second, many computer programming languages understand working with matrices quickly and efficiently.

XÂ = WÂ·I and OÂ = sigmoid (X) W is the matrix of weight, I is the matrix of inputs.

Learning weights from more than one node

The next step is to use the output from the neural network and compare it with the training example to work out an error. We used the error, the difference between what the node produced as an answer and what we know the answer should, to guide that refinement. So we use the proportion of weights to split the output error. In below graphs, the error e1 is split in proportion to the connected links, which have weight w11 and w21.

If we had even more layers, weâ€™d repeatedly apply this same idea to each layer working backwards from the final output layer.

How do we actually update weights

The mathematical expressions showing how all the weights result in a neural networkâ€™s output are too complex to easily untangle. Thus, we can use gradient descent method to find the minimum without actually having to understand functions. It is very necessary for us to refine without the size of the steps overshooting the minimum and forever bouncing around it.

To avoid ending up in the wrong valley, or function minimum, we train neural networks several times starting from different points on the hill to ensure we donâ€™t always ending up in the wrong valley. So this method is also resilient to imperfections in the data, we donâ€™t go wildly wrong if the function isnâ€™t quite perfectly.

Hereâ€™s the final answer weâ€™ve been working towards, the one that describes the slope of the error function so we can adjust the weight wjk. And we also use ğ›‚ as a learning rate

Preparing date

input

A very flat activation function is problematic because we use the gradient to learn new weights. A tiny gradient means weâ€™ve limited the ability to learn which called saturating a neural network. Besides, a very very tiny values can be problematic too because computers can lose accuracy when dealing very very small or very very large numbers. The good range of input is range 0.0 to 1.0. To avoid killing the learning ability by zeroing the weight update, zero inputs should not be included in.

output

The logistic function doesnâ€™t get to 1.0, and it just gets closer to it which is called this asymptotically approaching 1.0. If we do set target values in the inaccessible ranges, the training will drive ever large weights in an attempt to produce larger and larger output.

random initial weights

We should choose initial weights randomly and uniformly from range -1.0 to +1.0. and avoid large initial weights because they cause large signals into an activation function and undermine the effort we put into carefully scaling the input signals. Moreover, we donâ€™t set the initial weights the same constant value, especially. Obviously, zero weights can kill the input signal and error back propagating should not be divided equally.

DIY with Python

A very gentle start with Python

Class: we have created an object called sizzles from the Dog class definition and we can consider this object to be a dog. 

sizzles =  Dog() sizzles.bark()#initialisation method with internal datadef __init__(self, petname, temp):self.name = petname;self.temperaturn = temp:pass

The self. part means that the variables are part of this object and are independent of another Dog object or general variables in Python.

Neural network with Python

The skeleton code:

  • initialization: to set the number of input, hidden and output nodes.
  • train: refine the weights after being given a training set example to learn from.
  • query: give an answer from the output nodes after being given an input.

The most important part of the network is the link weights expressed as a matrix. Xhidden = Winput_hiddenx Â· I Ohidden = sigmoid Â· ( Xhidden )

Training the network:

  • working out the output for a given training example. That is no different to what we just did with the query() function.
  • taking this calculated output, comparing it with the desired output, and using the difference to guide the updating of the network weights.

The NMIST dataset of hand written numbers

There is my final codes backup on GIthub.

In the .cvs file, the first value is the label which is the actual digit that the handwriting is supposed to represent. The subsequent values means the original pictureâ€™s pixel values. We did see earlier how we might plot a rectangular array of numbers using the imshow() function. We want to do the same here but we need to convert that list of comma separated numbers into a suitable array. Split that long text string of comma separated values into individual values, using the commas as the place to do the splitting. Ignore the first value, which is the label, and take the remaining list of 28 x 28 = 784 values and turn them into an array which has a shape of 28 rows by 28 columns and plot the array.

Weâ€™ve deliberately chosen 0.01 as the lower end of the range to avoid the problems we saw earlier with zero valued inputs because they can artificially kill weight updates. We donâ€™t have to choose 0.99 for the upper end of the input because we donâ€™t need to avoid 1.0 for the inputs. Itâ€™s only for the outputs that we should avoid the impossible to reach 1.0.

By choosing a value smaller than the number of inputs, we force the network to try to summaries the key features. But if we choose too few hidden layer nodes, then we restrict the ability of the network to find sufficient features or patterns.

Finally, we can do some improvements.

  • The first improvement we can try is to adjust the learning rate. We set it at 0.3 previously without really experimenting with different values.
  • The next improvement we can do is to repeat the training several times against the data set. Some people call each run through an epoch.
  • Another idea is that the learning rate is too high for larger numbers of epochs.
  • Try changing the number of middle hidden layer nodes.

Even More Fun

Inside the mind of a neural network

Once a neural network is trained, and performs well enough on test data, we essentially have a mysterious black box. We donâ€™t really know howÂ it worksÂ out the answer - it just does.

Creating new training data: rotations

we could create new ones from those by rotating them clockwise and anti-clockwise, by 10 degrees for example. o by adding training examples with overly rotated images, we are reducing the quality of the training by adding false examples. Ten degrees seems to be the optimal angle for maximizing the value of additional data.

About me
---

Donâ€™t panic & Do more.
You can contact me on github
